name: Kirk Hammer
comment info:
1. I live in Milford, Delaware and I immediately searched for my county upon seeing the title of this graph. I noticed that I am particularly at risk for hurricanes, which--although we've had several--doesn't seem like it would be the most significant issue in my small state. I don't believe that we get nearly enough rainfall to be considered at risk for hurricanes.
2. Secondly, I wonder what this graph would correlate with. To elaborate, would states with higher sea level risks have more people who own boats? Or would people in CA--who are at risk for wildfires--be more likely to own a fire extinguisher compared to people who live in hurricane risk areas.
3. Finally, although this is completely irrelevant to the graph, I wondered why counties are shaped the way they are. The division of people into smaller classifications than states makes little to no sense to me, and the fact that there are counties in states like Nevada that are almost four times the size of my state boggles my mind.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Kirk Hammer I really like your perspective on this graph. You mentioned many interesting viewpoints that I didn't think about before. First of all, you raised the question about the graph's credibility by telling a first-hand experience you have living in one of the county in a hurricane state. Second, the questions you raised about how the weather would affect the way people live their lives such as owning a boat or fire extinguisher is very creative. Furthermore, the question of how county or state shape the way they are is also something worth mentioning. Overall, good job!! :)

name: Daren Masangcay
comment info: My country is San Mateo County in California, USA. The thing that I noticed is the chart is a big threat which is Water Stress coming in first, our second threat would be Extreme Heat, and then our third is Extreme Rainfall. But the main issue I want to talk about when noticing would be Water Stress. Water Stress to me most likely is about our water quality, water shortages, and water scarcity, which is a lack of fresh water. I wonder if this threat will be settled in the near future, and if it doesn't will we ever find a way to have drinkable water? This will impact me and my community because everyday, some people drink water to either be dehydrated, to help our bodies, or just be pleased with their lunches with water. If there is no more water then the question is, what are we going to drink? We can't keep drinking sodas because they're made from carbonated water and carbonated water is made from water. It's possible to stay alive without drinking water for a few days most likely, but that wouldn't be more effective to us. In the graph, water stress is a serious threat and is probably going to happen to other countries soon. A catchy headline that I can think of is, "What's going on with our water supply?"

name: Yaeli
comment info: I live on the border of San Mateo County, the two biggest climate threats are high water stress and high sea level rise. The first thing I noticed is that though the charts are based on climate threats and what not, natural disasters are overlooked. Earthquakes are a big part of California’s disasters especially since the sea level is rising. Since San Mateo’s sea level and water stress is very high, earthquakes could enhance more natural disasters like tsunamis and flooding, Of course we can’t forget about the frequent wildfires that constantly ruin our environment and air quality. My only question is, if California is always in danger of droughts, why is the water stress so high? In California there is little to no rain, with the exception of rainy winters and snowy areas like Lake Tahoe. I do wonder if it’s because San Mateo is located on the border of the U.S where many oceans lie. Earthquakes, wildfires, and  flooding play a big factor in many homes here. Although it’s sad to say, San Mateo County is poor and many communities would not be able to recover from big disasters like these. The graph is a perfect representation of our biggest climate problems and exhibits what we can do to help our community move forward. I would title the graph, “How much danger are we really in?”

comment info: In this graph of the week, I noticed that weather, temperature, and climate are all very diverse in the USA. Both sides of the country have struggles when it comes to the climate, and they are all very different. For example, the West Coast has a high risk of fires, and also seem to have water level risks. This has been a problem for a long time, and the fires do not seem to stop anytime soon. comment info: The first thing I did as many Americans did, I looked at my current home state. More than half of the state is prone to hurricane risk. Then the western part of the state is prone to heavy rainfall. If you look very closely, the far west of the state is prone to heat stress. To add to that if you look and go from east to west, the colors change in order which I find really interesting. The colors shift from dark green, to light green, to dark blue, to light blue, or pale orange, to full orange. This could have something to do with the way the state goes from beaches to the Appalachian mountains, but I’m no expert.

name: Clare H.
comment info:
I notice that the map has color sections, meaning that most of the country is separated into risk sections; the west having wildfires & water stress, the midwest having extreme heat, and the east having extreme rainfall and hurricane risks. I also notice that the west and east have completely different climates. The west coast is prone to fires, heatwaves, and extreme rainfall. The east coast, on the other hand, is prone to extreme rainfall and hurricanes. Though they're obviously so different, they're not that far away, and it is fascinating how something only 3000 miles away can have a completely different climate. I wonder why most of the midwest suffers from droughts & water stress. Though it is expected with climate change, I wonder what exactly makes such a difference. I also wonder why some areas of the color "sections" have different climates mixed in them. Look at California, for instance. They have a small section of extreme rainfall risk, so I wonder why they have rainfall, of all things, next to wildfire risk. This has an extreme impact on me and my community. When wildfire season starts, there's definitely nerves within my community. Though we haven't burned yet, we get the worst of the smoke in our area. name: Moderator Sharon

Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs:  “Could You Survive an Extreme Climate?  Well, You Might Just Be Living in One” by Max of Texas; “Nowhere Safe from the Effects of Climate Change” by Patrick from New York; "It Seems that the World is Divided Among the Parched and the Drenched" by Cooper of Durango, Colorado; “Mapping Out Climate Change “ by TES 8th Grade Science Class in Charlotte, North Carolina; and, "Is Your County at Extreme Risk for the Next Natural Disaster?" by Alyssa of Ohio.

Today’s map shows the greatest climate threats by U.S. county.  If you click on a county, you will see the six major threats evaluated for the county.

name: Sara (CJHS)
comment info:
Headline: Contrasting Climate Creates Calamity? Where is Our Country Headed?

I noticed that the climate across the US becomes wetter as you go east. In the west, wildfires plague the states due to dry conditions, and states in the middle of the country (not on the coast) are suffering due to water stress. Extreme heat hits the central-eastern parts, succeded by extreme rainfall and hurricanes near the coast. For Alaska, the sea level is rising, most likely due to ice in the north melting, and Hawaii's temperature is climbing steadily, possibly from the undersea volcanoes or from sunlight being absorbed by the ocean.

I wonder what the boundaries between certain climates are like. In the northern parts of California and Oregon, it shows that they are suffering from both extreme rainfal and wildfires. Head a little further east and there's water stress as well. Is it possible to have problems with all three of them in one state? I mean, wildfires and water stress I understand, but heavy rains should put out the wildfires and cure the water stress. It just seemed a little odd, is all.

comment info: This graph shows the different weather conditions across the United States. While the west coast is experiencing rainfall, wildfires, and water stress, the east coast has hurricanes and rainfall. I can infer that due to the many volcanoes that Hawaii includes, the weather has high heat stress. Within these categories, the severity in lighter or darker shades are shown in each county. For example, Shasta County displays darker red, meaning very high risk of wildfires. Neighboring it, is Lassen County showing a lighter shade to depict the lesser risk than Shasta. I wonder what occurred in Uvalde County in Texas to show high risk of wildfires. Why are there several counties in the mass of “extreme heat” showing high rainfall risk? The feature of searching a county and having it automatically highlighted is convenient.
